docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists say this could be a bad year for a rare but often fatal viral infection spread by rural rodents. Doctors are already recording slightly higher than usual numbers of hantavirus infections in some Western states, including Arizona, Colorado and New Mexico. Rangers are warning visitors to national parks not to feed or handle rodents, after a 7-year-old boy played with a possibly infected deer mouse that he caught on the remote Channel Islands off California.

headline.main: Threat of Virus Spread by Mice Rises in West

docs.lead_paragraph: You have a glass of white wine in one hand and a cracker in the other when that odd shooting pain starts up in your right hip again. But what luck -- standing right next to you at the buffet table, looking around for someone to talk to, is your second cousin Harry the doctor, a lovely guy, one of your favorite people and a noted hip expert. Don't do it.

headline.main: A Doctor Learns the Hard Way That Love and Medicine Don't Mix

docs.lead_paragraph: You've heard it now for years: fiber is good for you. Eat more whole grains, dried peas and beans, fruits and vegetables if you want to stay healthy. Fiber protects the colon against cancer. It also helps the heart by lowering cholesterol, reduces the risk of developing diabetes and facilitates weight control. Then along comes a widely publicized Harvard study of nearly 89,000 nurses that seems to derail the fiber bandwagon. The study, published this year in The New England Journal of Medicine, found no greater protection from colon cancer among the women who consumed the highest amount of fiber, more than 25 grams a day, than among those who consumed the least fiber, less than 10 grams a day.

headline.main: Keep the Fiber Bandwagon Rolling, for Heart and Health

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people feel alarmed when they begin to experience numbness and tingling in their hands and wrists, assuming that they must have carpal tunnel syndrome, the sometimes disabling nerve disorder. Now a new study -- the most comprehensive to date -- finds that they are often wrong, although the disease is more prevalent than had been expected. As many as 1 in 5 people with these symptoms -- characteristic of the family of diseases known as repetitive strain injury -- have the syndrome, in which a nerve becomes pinched in the wrist, the researchers found. An estimated 200,000 people in the United States have surgery each year to repair the condition, often paid for by workers' compensation programs.

headline.main: Common but Confusing: Workers' Wrist Ailments

docs.lead_paragraph: Elementary schoolchildren who were taught healthy behaviors in a National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute preventive health trial are still practicing them three years later, according to a follow-up study that examined the children's food and fitness behaviors over time. The results appear in the current Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine. From 1991 to 1994, the institute financed the Child and Adolescent Trial for Cardiovascular Health, or Catch, study, the largest school-based health promotion research project in the United States. In it, third graders at 56 elementary schools in four states participated.

headline.main: An Early Start for Healthier Habits

docs.lead_paragraph: The vast majority of Americans will suffer from back pain at some point in their lives. In fact, only the common cold causes more employee absenteeism. Now, a study in the current issue of Science indicates that one of the most common back problems, intervertebral disk disease, or sciatica, may be an inherited disorder. Sciatica is a painful condition in the region of the lower back and hip, affecting about half of all people with serious back conditions.

docs.lead_paragraph: At age 11, Julie Swail of Placentia, Calif., wangled her way out of swim practice by picking up the slack in a boys' water polo game being played in an adjacent pool. By the final whistle, she knew she had found her sport. ''It was physical, aggressive and required a lot of endurance, everything I was looking for and hadn't found in swimming,'' she said. Now 26, Ms. Swail is captain of the United States national women's water polo team. She and her teammates will make history this week as they head to Canada for their first outing in the Pan American Games. And, women's water polo for the first time will be an Olympic sport when the Games convene in Sydney next year.

headline.main: Women Make Water Polo Their Own

docs.lead_paragraph: Long-distance runners and others performing strenuous exercises have long known that they should eat carbohydrates after workouts to replace the energy stores they have exhausted. Now a report in The Journal of Nutrition suggests that eating meat, dairy products and protein bars containing the amino acid leucine after intense exercise also significantly cuts down on the time muscles need to recover, at least in rats. During exercise, some of the protein that makes up muscles is broken down, preventing them from working fully. But leucine, an amino acid, or protein component, appears to spark the first step in creating, or synthesizing, protein, leading to muscle renewal. ''Our research shows that consuming food with leucine after exercising starts the recovery process right away,'' said Dr. Donald K. Layman, an exercise scientist at the University of Illinois. ''The quicker an exerciser recovers, the sooner he or she can operate at peak capacity. When you are at less than full recovery, you give a less than full performance,'' Dr. Layman said.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in 20 years, medical researchers will soon test in people a vaccine against group A streptococcus, the bug that causes strep throat and rheumatic fever and is feared as the ''flesh-eating'' bacterium. Work on such vaccines nearly dried up after some children who received an experimental vaccine about 30 years ago developed rheumatic fever, raising fears that the vaccine could cause a disease it was meant to prevent.

headline.main: Tests on Strep Vaccine Restart, Gingerly
